title: If you had to choose between death of yourself or death of someone you never knew, how would you make your decision? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m going to make a few presuppositions. First, the victim dies after falling asleep, silent and sudden. I won’t bother with the details on how. Second, I am forced to make a choice. I can’t not decide. On one hand, I can choose death for myself, certain about who exactly would be the ones to be pained and affected by my choice. On the other hand, I can choose death for someone I don’t know, uncertain of who I’m making suffer. With the latter choice, there is a lot more variables to deal with. Who are they close with? Who care for and spend the most time with him? I don’t even know what he’s like so I don’t know how his friendships are. I don’t know his qualities, his flaws, what makes him likable, the things he’s done, how he thinks, etc - for better or worse. I know nothing. And because I know nothing, I’m ignorant of him, who he’s influenced, and those who care for him. I can choose certainty, along with knowing who exactly I’m hurting. Or uncertainty, ignorant of who I may have hurt and in what ways. Despite my choice, somebody will feel guilty. My family may feel guilty and sad, dwelling on how they might have been able to prevent my death. Or I’ll carry that guilt with me as I move forward in life. The family and friends of the stranger in a similar place to mine in the previous scenario. I certainly do value who I know now more than who I don’t. And I’ll probably feel more awful harming those I value instead of those I’ve never encountered. Besides, I don’t know if who fell to the grave before me was liked or not. If he was cared for. It’s possible he may not have, though I don’t deny other possibilities. I’d rather choose uncertainty, where it’s possible that this person was in a bad spot instead of choosing a scenario where you are certain of who and how you’re hurting those you care about. The best choice doesn't always have to be the right choice.

I’d have to ask myself some questions. First, do I love myself? Second, do I like my life as it currently stands? Three, if I hate my life more than I love myself, does that mean I love someone else’s life more than my own? Fourth, do I see the strangers’ death, or vice verse? Overall, none of those questions matter, but it matters as to how I was raised, the morals and values that were instilled in me long ago. I was raised in a military family - both grandfathers served, my father and his brother, multiple other uncles, my brother, and multiple cousins served, as well as I. My dad retired from the service and went into law enforcement. I wasn’t a religious man growing up, but I’ve come to terms with it (religion). What all that means in conclusion is that we may be strangers, you and I (or the unknown person that I have the option to let die), but if it came to the fact that I had to lay down my life so another may live, I have been well prepared in doing so. In closing, found In the Bible, John 15:13 states quite clearly, “Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends.“ Now, again, we may not know each other now, but I believe sooner or later, we will meet - be it this side or the other of the veil of death is unknown, but we will, and we will all be friends. The same goes for that stranger that I will die for so that they may live.
